lessons.title: ADHD Coaching Foundation
lessons.subtitle: Understanding neurodivergent strengths and your scope of practice

sections.content: Hey {name}! Welcome to your ADHD Coach Certification journey. You are stepping into one of the most impactful and desperately needed coaching specialties in the world right now. Over 300 million adults worldwide have ADHD, and most of them are not getting the support they need. Therapists focus on emotions. Doctors focus on medication. But who helps ADHD adults build the practical systems, strategies, and structures that actually make daily life work? That is you. That is what an ADHD coach does. And the world cannot train them fast enough.
What ADHD Really Is

ADHD is a **neurodevelopmental condition** that affects the brain's executive functions, the mental processes that help us plan, focus, remember, start tasks, regulate emotions, and manage time. It is not a character flaw. It is not laziness. It is not something people can just 'try harder' to overcome. The ADHD brain is structurally and chemically different from a neurotypical brain, particularly in the prefrontal cortex and in the production of **dopamine and norepinephrine**, the neurotransmitters that regulate attention, motivation, and reward.

ADHD is not a deficit of attention. It is a problem with regulating attention. People with ADHD can hyperfocus intensely on things they find stimulating while struggling enormously with tasks that are boring but necessary. The name 'Attention Deficit Disorder' is actually misleading. A more accurate name would be 'Attention Regulation Disorder.'

sections.question: What is the core issue in ADHD?
options: A lack of intelligence or motivation
A problem with regulating attention and executive functions
A personality disorder caused by bad parenting
A condition that only affects children
sections.explanation: ADHD is a neurodevelopmental condition that affects the brain's executive functions and attention regulation. It is not about intelligence, motivation, or character. The ADHD brain processes dopamine differently, which affects focus, planning, and emotional regulation.

sections.content: The Three Presentations of ADHD

ADHD presents differently in different people, which is one reason so many adults go undiagnosed for decades. Understanding these presentations helps you recognize ADHD in potential clients and tailor your coaching approach.
The three ADHD presentations:
items: **Predominantly Inattentive** — Difficulty sustaining focus, easily distracted, forgetful in daily activities, loses things, appears to be daydreaming. This presentation is frequently missed in women and girls because it does not involve hyperactivity.
**Predominantly Hyperactive-Impulsive** — Restless, fidgety, talks excessively, interrupts others, acts without thinking, difficulty waiting. This is the stereotypical ADHD that most people picture.
**Combined Type** — Shows significant symptoms of both inattention and hyperactivity-impulsivity. This is the most commonly diagnosed presentation in adults.

sections.content: Women with ADHD are dramatically underdiagnosed because the inattentive presentation is quieter and less disruptive. Many women are not diagnosed until their 30s, 40s, or later, after decades of struggling and blaming themselves. As a coach, you will likely work with many women experiencing a late diagnosis who need both practical strategies and compassionate support.
Neurodivergent Strengths

ADHD is not all struggle. The same brain wiring that creates challenges also creates genuine **superpowers**. As a coach, your job is not to 'fix' people. It is to help them leverage their unique brain wiring while managing the challenges. This strength-based approach is what separates great ADHD coaches from everyone else.
Genuine ADHD strengths you will help clients leverage:
items: **Creativity and innovation** — ADHD brains make unexpected connections between ideas that neurotypical brains miss
**Hyperfocus** — When engaged, ADHD brains can achieve extraordinary depth of focus and productivity
**Crisis performance** — Many ADHD adults thrive under pressure and deadlines when dopamine spikes
**Energy and enthusiasm** — ADHD passion is contagious and can inspire teams and communities
**Pattern recognition** — The ability to see connections across disparate fields and ideas
**Resilience** — Years of overcoming daily challenges builds extraordinary toughness and adaptability

sections.title: Why is ADHD coaching one of the fastest-growing specialties?
sections.content: The demand for ADHD coaches is exploding for several reasons. Adult ADHD diagnoses have increased over 120 percent in the past decade as awareness has grown. Medication helps many people, but it does not teach the practical skills, systems, and strategies that adults need to manage work, relationships, finances, and daily life. Therapists address the emotional impact of ADHD, but most are not trained to provide the practical, action-oriented coaching that creates real-world change. ADHD coaches fill this critical gap. The market is growing at 25 percent or more annually, ADHD coaches typically charge $150 to $300 per session, and many have waitlists within their first year of practice. You are entering this field at exactly the right time.
The Executive Function Challenges

Executive functions are the brain's management system. Think of them as the mental CEO that organizes, plans, initiates, and completes tasks. In ADHD, these functions are not absent. They are **inconsistent and unreliable**. This inconsistency is actually one of the most frustrating aspects of ADHD. A client might brilliantly manage a crisis at work one day and then be unable to start laundry the next. This is not laziness. It is brain chemistry.
The key executive function challenges you will address as an ADHD coach:
items: **Working Memory** — Holding information in mind while using it. Walking into a room and forgetting why.
**Time Blindness** — A genuinely different experience of time where hours pass like minutes or minutes feel like hours
**Task Initiation** — The inability to start tasks, even important ones, despite knowing they need to be done
**Emotional Regulation** — Intense emotions that feel overwhelming, including Rejection Sensitive Dysphoria
**Organization** — Difficulty keeping track of things, materials, schedules, and commitments
**Self-Motivation** — Struggling to do things without external rewards, deadlines, or accountability

sections.content: Scope of Practice

As an ASI-certified ADHD Coach, you operate within a clear professional scope. Understanding these boundaries is essential for your credibility, your clients' safety, and your ability to work alongside other professionals.
What you DO as a certified ADHD Coach:
items: Help clients build practical systems for time management, organization, and task completion
Provide accountability, structure, and support for achieving goals
Educate clients about how ADHD affects their brain and daily functioning
Help clients identify and leverage their neurodivergent strengths
Support clients in developing emotional regulation strategies
Collaborate with therapists, doctors, and other professionals in the client's care team

sections.content: What you do NOT do as an ADHD Coach:
items: Diagnose ADHD or any other medical or mental health condition
Prescribe or recommend medication changes
Provide therapy or treat clinical depression, anxiety, or trauma
Replace medical or psychiatric care
Interpret psychological assessments or testing results

sections.content: Your scope of practice is your greatest asset. When therapists and psychiatrists see that you operate professionally within clear boundaries, they will refer their ADHD patients to you for the practical coaching they cannot provide in therapy sessions. Staying in scope builds trust and grows your practice through referrals.

sections.question: Which of the following is within an ADHD Coach's scope of practice?
options: Diagnosing a client with ADHD after observing their symptoms
Helping a client build practical systems for time management and organization
Recommending that a client change their medication dosage
Providing therapy for the client's childhood trauma
sections.explanation: ADHD coaches help clients build practical systems, strategies, and structures for managing daily life. Diagnosis, medication, and therapy are outside your scope and should be handled by qualified medical and mental health professionals.

sections.question: Can you see yourself helping people with ADHD unlock their potential and build lives that work with their brains?
sections.yesText: Yes, I'm ready to learn how!
sections.noText: I need to learn more first

keyTakeaways: ADHD is a neurodevelopmental condition affecting executive functions and attention regulation — it is not laziness, and it comes with genuine strengths like creativity, hyperfocus, and resilience

lessons.title: The D.E.P.T.H. Method™
lessons.subtitle: Your systematic framework for ADHD coaching sessions

sections.content: Welcome back, {name}! Now that you understand what ADHD is, how it affects the brain, and your scope of practice, it is time to learn HOW to actually coach ADHD clients. The D.E.P.T.H. Method gives you a structured, repeatable framework that transforms your ADHD knowledge into a professional coaching process that delivers real results and keeps clients committed to their growth.
Why ADHD Clients Need a Framework

Here is the irony of ADHD coaching: the very people who need structure the most are the people whose brains resist structure the most. ADHD clients have tried countless productivity systems, planners, and self-help strategies that failed because they were designed for **neurotypical brains**. They come to you feeling broken, ashamed, and skeptical that anything will work. The D.E.P.T.H. Method is different because it is built specifically for how ADHD brains actually function. It works WITH the ADHD brain, not against it.

The D.E.P.T.H. Method is not another productivity system that will make your clients feel like failures. It is a coaching framework that meets them where they are, respects their brain wiring, and builds practical strategies that are customized to their unique presentation of ADHD.
The D.E.P.T.H. Method™ Framework

steps.title: Discover
steps.description: Conduct a comprehensive ADHD coaching intake. Explore the client's ADHD history (when diagnosed, what type, current treatment), their biggest daily struggles, what strategies they have tried, their work and relationship challenges, their strengths and passions, and what they want most from coaching. Understand their unique ADHD presentation — no two ADHD brains are the same.

steps.title: Evaluate
steps.description: Assess which executive function challenges are creating the most disruption in their daily life. Is time blindness making them chronically late and missing deadlines? Is task initiation paralyzing them? Is emotional dysregulation damaging their relationships? Is disorganization creating chaos at home and work? Most clients have 2-3 primary executive function challenges that are driving most of their struggles.

steps.title: Plan
steps.description: Co-create an ADHD-friendly action plan with specific, practical strategies for their top challenges. This plan must be realistic, flexible, and built around their strengths. Use 2-4 week experiment cycles rather than rigid long-term plans. ADHD brains need novelty and quick feedback, so short cycles keep motivation alive and allow rapid adjustment.

steps.title: Transform
steps.description: Implement strategies through regular coaching sessions that provide the external accountability and structure ADHD brains need. This is where you teach ADHD-specific tools: body doubling, time boxing, visual timers, habit stacking, environmental design, and emotional regulation techniques. Each session reviews what worked, what did not, and adjusts the approach. Progress, not perfection.

steps.title: Heal
steps.description: Support the deeper transformation: rebuilding self-trust, releasing shame from years of 'failure,' developing self-compassion, and creating a sustainable relationship with their ADHD brain. Many clients need to grieve the neurotypical life they thought they should have before they can fully embrace the neurodivergent life that actually works for them. This phase transitions from active coaching to maintenance and empowerment.

sections.content: D — Discover: The ADHD Coaching Intake

Your intake session is the foundation of everything that follows. ADHD clients often come to you feeling defeated after years of failed strategies. They need to feel **heard, understood, and not judged** before they will trust your coaching. Your intake is not just information gathering. It is the beginning of a relationship built on genuine understanding of their unique ADHD experience.
Essential ADHD coaching intake questions:
items: When were you diagnosed? What was that experience like? (Or do you suspect ADHD but are not yet diagnosed?)
What are your biggest daily struggles right now? What causes the most stress or shame?
What strategies or systems have you tried before? What worked, even temporarily, and what completely failed?
How does ADHD affect your work? Your relationships? Your self-image?
What are you naturally good at? When do you feel most alive and focused?
Are you currently on medication? Working with a therapist or psychiatrist?
If coaching could change one thing in your life in the next 90 days, what would it be?

sections.content: Many ADHD clients have never had someone ask about their strengths. They are so used to being defined by their deficits that hearing 'What are you naturally good at?' can be an emotional moment. Start there. Build from strengths. It changes the entire coaching dynamic.

sections.question: Why is the Discover phase especially important for ADHD clients?
options: To diagnose their specific type of ADHD
To build trust and understand their unique ADHD experience before introducing strategies
To immediately assign them a productivity system
To evaluate whether they should change their medication
sections.explanation: ADHD clients often arrive feeling defeated after years of failed strategies. The Discover phase builds trust, gathers essential information about their unique ADHD presentation, and creates a foundation of understanding before any strategies are introduced.

sections.content: E — Evaluate: Identifying the Core Challenges

After your intake, you evaluate which **executive function challenges** are creating the most disruption. A client who is constantly late, misses deadlines, and underestimates how long everything takes has a primary challenge with **time blindness**. Someone who knows exactly what they need to do but cannot get themselves to start has a **task initiation** problem. A client whose relationships are suffering because of emotional outbursts or rejection sensitivity has an **emotional regulation** challenge. Most clients have 2 to 3 primary challenges that drive the majority of their daily struggles.

Do not try to fix everything at once. ADHD clients are already overwhelmed. Identify the top 2 to 3 executive function challenges, then prioritize the one that will create the most relief when addressed first. Small wins build momentum, and momentum builds confidence. Confidence changes everything for an ADHD brain.
P — Plan: ADHD-Friendly Strategy Design

This is where your ADHD-specific knowledge becomes critical. You do not hand clients a generic planner and say 'write everything down.' You **co-create** strategies that are designed for how ADHD brains actually work. The key principles are: externalize what the brain cannot internalize, make the invisible visible, reduce friction to starting, and build in novelty so the brain stays engaged.
ADHD-friendly strategy principles:
items: **Externalize everything** — If the brain cannot remember, put it outside the brain (visual timers, phone alarms, sticky notes, body doubling)
**2-4 week experiments** — Never commit to a strategy 'forever.' Try it for 2 weeks, evaluate, adjust. ADHD brains need novelty.
**Ridiculously small steps** — Make the first step so easy the brain cannot resist. 'Open the laptop' instead of 'finish the report.'
**Build on strengths** — If they hyperfocus on creative work, design their schedule around those windows
**Good enough over perfect** — Perfect systems get abandoned. Functional systems that are 70 percent consistent change lives.
**Expect breaks** — ADHD brains will fall off systems. Plan for restarts, not perfection.

sections.content: T — Transform: The Coaching Sessions

Your regular coaching sessions are where transformation happens. ADHD brains need **external accountability and structure** that coaching uniquely provides. Each session follows a simple but powerful rhythm: review what happened since the last session, celebrate wins (even small ones), troubleshoot what did not work, adjust strategies, and set intentions for the next period.
Core ADHD coaching tools you will use in Transform sessions:
items: **Body doubling** — Working alongside someone else (even virtually) for accountability and focus
**Time boxing** — Assigning fixed time blocks to tasks rather than working 'until done'
**Visual timers** — Making time visible with tools like Time Timer or simple hourglasses
**Habit stacking** — Linking new habits to existing behaviors as anchors ('After I pour coffee, I take my meds')
**Environmental design** — Setting up physical spaces that reduce friction and distraction
**Emotional regulation tools** — The HALT check (Hungry, Angry, Lonely, Tired), naming emotions, the 24-hour rule before responding

sections.content: Celebrate every win, especially the small ones. ADHD clients are so used to focusing on failures that acknowledging progress, even saying 'You remembered to use your timer three times this week, that is huge,' can completely shift their self-image. Never underestimate the power of being seen for what is working.
H — Heal: Rebuilding Self-Trust

The Heal phase addresses something most ADHD strategies ignore: the **emotional damage** from years of struggling with an unrecognized or unsupported brain difference. Many ADHD adults carry deep shame, a belief that they are lazy, broken, or not living up to their potential. Practical strategies alone will not undo decades of negative self-talk. The Heal phase helps clients release that shame, develop self-compassion, and build a new identity as someone whose brain works differently, not deficiently.
Key Heal phase elements:
items: Grieving the neurotypical life they thought they should have
Reframing ADHD from deficit to difference with genuine strengths
Building self-compassion practices for when old patterns resurface
Recognizing and interrupting shame spirals before they derail progress
Transitioning from active coaching to maintenance and self-directed growth

sections.title: What does a real D.E.P.T.H. Method ADHD coaching journey look like?
sections.content: A 38-year-old woman diagnosed with ADHD at 35 comes to you feeling like a fraud. She is intelligent, creative, and successful in bursts, but her life is chaos: missed deadlines, forgotten appointments, piles of unfinished projects, and a marriage strained by her unreliability. In the Discover phase, you learn she was the 'smart but lazy' kid who compensated with last-minute crisis performance. You Evaluate and identify time blindness and task initiation as her primary executive function challenges. You Plan a 2-week experiment: visual timers on her desk, time-boxing her top 3 daily tasks, and a body-doubling session with a friend twice a week. In Transform sessions over 8 weeks, you refine these strategies. She starts meeting deadlines consistently for the first time in her career. Her husband notices the change. In the Heal phase, she breaks down crying as she realizes she was never lazy. She was fighting a brain that no one understood. She refers two colleagues to you within a month.

sections.question: Why does the D.E.P.T.H. Method use 2-4 week experiment cycles instead of long-term plans?
options: Because ADHD clients cannot commit to anything longer
Because ADHD brains need novelty and quick feedback to stay engaged, and short cycles allow rapid adjustment
Because strategies never work for more than 2 weeks
Because coaches cannot plan further ahead than that
sections.explanation: ADHD brains are wired for novelty and immediate feedback. Long-term rigid plans feel overwhelming and get abandoned. Short experiment cycles keep motivation alive, provide quick wins, and allow strategies to be adjusted based on what actually works for each unique client.

sections.question: Can you see how the D.E.P.T.H. Method gives you the confidence and structure to coach real ADHD clients?
sections.yesText: Yes, this makes ADHD coaching feel doable!
sections.noText: I want to learn more about the tools

sections.content: What Is Coming Next

In the final lesson, you will learn exactly how to get your first ADHD coaching clients, set your pricing, and build a practice that generates $5,000 or more per month while doing deeply meaningful, life-changing work.

keyTakeaways: The D.E.P.T.H. Method provides a structured coaching framework built specifically for ADHD brains: Discover their unique experience, Evaluate executive function challenges, Plan ADHD-friendly strategies, Transform through accountability sessions, and Heal the emotional damage from years of struggling
ADHD coaching strategies must externalize what the brain cannot internalize, use short experiment cycles, start ridiculously small, and build on strengths rather than just fixing deficits
The Heal phase addresses the shame and negative self-image that years of unrecognized ADHD create — practical strategies alone are not enough without rebuilding self-trust

lessons.title: How To Get Your First Clients
lessons.subtitle: Build a thriving ADHD coaching practice from day one

sections.content: Congratulations, {name}! You now understand ADHD at a foundational level AND you have the D.E.P.T.H. Method to guide every client through a structured coaching journey. But ADHD knowledge without clients means your coaching gift stays locked inside you. In this final lesson, you will learn the exact strategy to get your first paying clients and build an ADHD coaching practice that sustains both your purpose and your finances.
The Warm Market Strategy

Your first clients are **not** strangers on social media. They are people who already know you and trust you. Think about the people in your life who have said things like 'I cannot focus on anything,' 'I am always running late no matter what I try,' 'My house is a disaster and I do not know where to start,' or 'I feel like I am not living up to my potential.' Those people are your first clients. Many of them may have ADHD and not even know it yet. And even those who are diagnosed are likely not getting the coaching support they need.
Your warm market includes people who already trust you:
items: Friends or family members who have been diagnosed with ADHD or who show clear signs of executive function struggles
People in your life who talk about being chronically disorganized, forgetful, or overwhelmed
Colleagues who are clearly brilliant but struggle with deadlines, follow-through, or consistency
Members of ADHD support groups, online communities, or Facebook groups you belong to
Parents who have children with ADHD and are exhausted, overwhelmed, and looking for guidance
Anyone who has ever said 'What is wrong with me? I know what I need to do but I just cannot make myself do it.'

sections.content: The Conversation Framework

When someone shares a struggle that ADHD coaching can help with, here is exactly what to say: **'I just completed a professional certification in ADHD coaching. I am working with a small number of clients right now. Would you be open to a free 15-minute conversation to see if coaching might help with what you are going through?'** This is not a sales pitch. It is a genuine offer of support from a trained professional. Most people will say yes because they already trust you and they are already struggling.

If you have ADHD yourself, your personal experience is your greatest marketing asset. When you say 'I understand because I live with this too,' it builds instant trust and connection that no amount of credentials alone can create. Your lived experience combined with your certification is incredibly powerful.

sections.question: What is the fastest path to getting your first ADHD coaching clients?
options: Building a website and waiting for traffic
Running paid ads on Instagram
Reaching out to your warm market with a genuine offer
Getting referrals from psychiatrists before starting
sections.explanation: Your warm market is people who already know and trust you. Many of them are already struggling with ADHD challenges and telling you about them. With your certification, you can now offer professional coaching support and start building your practice immediately.

sections.content: Pricing Your ADHD Coaching Services

People with ADHD invest thousands in medication, therapy, productivity apps, courses, planners, and self-help books that do not address the core issue: they need **practical coaching and accountability** designed specifically for their brain. Your guided ADHD coaching practice delivers what all those other solutions miss. Price your services to reflect the transformation you provide, not the time you spend.
Recommended starter pricing structure:
items: Discovery call: **Free** (15 minutes to assess fit and explain your coaching process)
Single coaching session (50 min): **$125 to $175**
Starter Package — 4 sessions over 4 weeks: **$297** (best entry point for new clients)
90-Day ADHD Transformation — 12 sessions: **$1,497 to $2,497** (your premium offer)
Monthly maintenance coaching: **$197 to $297** per month (biweekly sessions for ongoing support)

sections.content: Always lead with a package over single sessions. A single ADHD coaching session is like reading one chapter of a book and expecting your life to change. Real transformation requires consistent coaching, accountability, and strategy refinement over time. Your $297 starter package gives clients enough sessions to experience real results, which leads to them investing in your deeper 90-day program.
Your Income Potential

The math is straightforward and exciting. If you enroll just **5 clients per month** in your $297 starter package, that is **$1,485 per month**. If 3 of those clients upgrade to your 90-Day ADHD Transformation at $1,800, that is another **$5,400**. Add 4 monthly maintenance clients at $247 each and you are at **$7,873 per month**, working approximately 15 to 20 hours per week. Many ADHD coaches reach $8,000 to $12,000 per month within their first year because the demand is so high.
The Free Discovery Call

Your free 15-minute discovery call is the bridge between a casual conversation and a paying client. ADHD clients especially need to feel understood before they will invest. During this call, you listen to their biggest struggles, briefly explain how ADHD coaching works and what the D.E.P.T.H. Method process looks like, and then offer your starter package. You are not convincing anyone. You are presenting a solution to a problem they already told you they have.
Discovery call structure:
items: Listen: Ask what their biggest ADHD challenges are and what they have tried before (5 minutes)
Validate: Acknowledge that their struggles are real and not their fault — this is brain wiring, not character (2 minutes)
Educate: Briefly explain how ADHD coaching works differently from therapy or medication (3 minutes)
Offer: Present your starter package and let them decide without pressure (5 minutes)
If they say yes, book the first session immediately while their momentum is high

sections.content: ADHD clients often struggle with follow-through on decisions. If someone says yes on the discovery call, book the first session right then and there. Send them a calendar invite and a confirmation text immediately. Reducing the gap between decision and action is an ADHD-friendly practice that starts the coaching relationship the right way.
Scope of Practice Reminder

As you build your practice, always honor your scope. You provide practical ADHD coaching: systems, strategies, accountability, and strength-based support. You help clients build lives that work with their brains. You refer to psychiatrists for diagnosis and medication questions, to therapists for clinical depression, anxiety disorders, and trauma, and to other specialists as appropriate. **Staying in scope is what makes you trustworthy and referable.** When mental health professionals see that you operate within clear boundaries, they will send their ADHD clients to you for the coaching they cannot provide.

sections.question: Why should you lead with a package rather than single coaching sessions?
options: Because single sessions are not profitable enough
Because ADHD clients need consistent coaching and accountability over time to experience real transformation
Because packages are easier to schedule
Because clients prefer longer commitments
sections.explanation: Real ADHD transformation requires consistent coaching, accountability, and strategy refinement over time. A single session is like reading one chapter of a book. Packages give clients enough sessions to build, test, and refine strategies that actually work for their unique brain.

sections.content: Your 30-Day Launch Plan
Follow this plan to get your first clients within 30 days:
items: Week 1: List 20 people in your life who struggle with focus, organization, time management, or follow-through. Reach out to 5 with your free discovery call offer.
Week 2: Conduct free 15-minute discovery calls. Offer your $297 starter package to those who are ready. Join 2-3 ADHD online communities and start contributing value.
Week 3: Share your certification journey on social media. Post about common ADHD struggles and practical tips. Let people come to you with questions.
Week 4: Follow up with everyone you spoke to. Ask your first clients for testimonials and referrals. Reach out to local therapists and psychiatrists to introduce your coaching services.

sections.content: The Value of Your ASI Certification

In the ADHD coaching space, credibility matters enormously. Clients need to know you are trained, ethical, and professional. Therapists and psychiatrists need to trust that you will operate within scope before they refer patients to you. Your ASI certification from the AccrediPro Standards Institute signals that you have completed rigorous training, understand ADHD at a professional level, and follow clear standards of practice. It separates you from the countless life coaches who add 'ADHD' to their title without any specialized training.

Certified ADHD coaches report significantly higher client retention and faster practice growth compared to uncertified coaches. Your credential is not just a certificate. It is a trust accelerator that gives clients, families, and referring professionals the confidence to work with you.

sections.title: What if I have ADHD myself and worry I cannot run a coaching business?
sections.content: This is one of the most common concerns new ADHD coaches face, and here is the truth: having ADHD does not disqualify you from coaching. It qualifies you. You understand the struggles from the inside in a way that neurotypical coaches never will. The key is to use the same tools you will teach your clients: external accountability, time boxing, body doubling, visual systems, and simple structures. Many of the most successful ADHD coaches in the world have ADHD themselves. They design ADHD-friendly businesses with flexible schedules, clear systems, and built-in accountability. Your D.E.P.T.H. Method training gives you both the coaching framework AND the business structure to succeed with an ADHD brain. You do not need to be neurotypical to change lives. You just need to be trained, committed, and willing to practice what you preach.
